title: Fixing electromagnetic units

content.raw: How is that not right?  `1 G = 10^-4 T`, so `1G = 10^-4 * 10^9 nT = 10^5 nT`.

content.html: Stuart Mumford care to have another look at this?

description:
Currently, we define everything in terms of cgs base units, which are centimeters, grams, and seconds (we add in Kelvin and radians for good measure). In cgs, even the electromagnetic units are expressed in terms of these base units. 

SI, however, has Ampere as a base unit, so that, for example, while in cgs:

```python
q = YTQuantity(1.0,"esu")
print q.in_cgs()
```
```pycon
1.0 cm**(3/2)*sqrt(g)/s
```

in SI:

```python
q = YTQuantity(1.0,"C")
print q.in_mks()
```
```pycon
1.0 A*s
```

From when they were introduced up until now, the SI EM units were based on Ampere, without regarding it as a base unit itself, even though it has a completely different dimension than any of our CGS base units. 

There is also the other issue of translations between cgs <-> SI EM units. Our unit system relies on checking dimensions for unit equivalency. However, electrostatic units and Coulombs are both units of charge, but they don't have the same dimensions. So, up until this point, we translated between cgs <-> SI by a hack, where we treat those translations as a special case and ignore the fact that the dimensions aren't equivalent.

So, you could do things like this:

```python
from yt.utilities.physical_constants import qp
qp_mks = qp.in_units("C")
print qp, qp.units.dimensions
print qp_mks, qp_mks.units.dimensions
```
```pycon
4.8032056e-10 esu (length)**(3/2)*sqrt((mass))/(time)
1.60217693001e-19 C (current_mks)*(time)
```

and:

```python
B = YTQuantity(1.0,"T")
B_cgs = B.in_units("gauss")
print B, B.units.dimensions
print B_cgs, B_cgs.units.dimensions
```
```pycon
1.0 T (mass)/((current_mks)*(time)**2)
10000.0 gauss sqrt((mass))/(sqrt((length))*(time))
```

However, as Issue #1004 showed, these hacks were not sufficient to keep all of the unit translations self-consistent:

```python
B.in_mks()
```
```pycon
29979245800.0 kg/(A*s**2) # WRONG!
```

That one is particularly egregious since the definition of a Tesla in SI base units is `1 kg/(A*s*s)`.

I tried to find a way to resolve these issues by altering the current state of the code in minor ways, but I always found out that I was never able to resolve all of them self-consistently. The only way to fix them in the current setup would be to introduce more ugly hacks. 

So, this PR represents the following solution:

1. Get rid of the hacks that translate between SI and cgs EM units when they don't have the same dimension. Stick strictly to the behavior where we can only translate any unit to another when they have the same dimension.

2. Handle translations between SI and cgs EM units by a unit equivalency. 

3. Expand our definition of "base units" to include the "Ampere". This is potentially controversial, as we have always defined our base units to be cgs, which don't have the notion of a separate current dimension. My proposal is that we have the following set of base units, without refering to them as "cgs", but simply as "base units":

```python
yt_base_units = {
    dimensions.mass:'g',
    dimensions.length:'cm',
    dimensions.time:'s',
    dimensions.temperature:'K',
    dimensions.angle:'radian',
    dimensions.current_mks:'A',
}
```

Every unit we have can be reduced to a combination of these. 

What follows on from this is that, for internal consistency and to reduce confusion, we no longer should refer to these units anywhere in the code as "cgs" but as simply our "base units". In that vein, I have replaced the `Unit` attribute `cgs_value` with `base_value`, and added methods to `YTArray` such as `in_base`, `convert_to_base`, which will get you to base units of any quantity. `in_cgs`, `in_mks`, etc. are intact and should retain the same behavior. If you try to convert something which has "Ampere" as a base unit to cgs, you will get an error:

```python
Q = YTQuantity(1.0,"C")
print Q.in_mks()
print Q.in_cgs()
```
```pycon
1.0 A*s
YTUnitsNotReducible: The unit 'C' cannot be reduced to a single expression within the cgs base system of units.
```

The impact of having these new methods to convert to "base" units is minimal at this point, but my hope is that this will serve as a starting point for eventually allowing a different set of base units to be specified, which is of course another can of worms and another PR. 

I have put the appropriate hooks into the code so that if someone tries to convert, say, between Tesla and Gauss as before, they will get a helpful error message:

```python
B = YTQuantity(1.0,"gauss")
print B.in_units("nT")
```
```pycon
YTEquivalentDimsError: It looks like you're trying to convert between 'gauss' and 'nT'. Try using "to_equivalent('nT', 'SI')" instead.
```

So this should now be done instead:

```python
print B.to_equivalent("nT", "SI")
```
```pycon
100000.0 nT
```

The reverse direction works like this:
```python
I = YTQuantity(1.0,"A")
print I.to_equivalent("esu/s","CGS")
```
```pycon
2997924580.0 esu/s
```

This PR also adds units and dimensions for electric potential and resistance, as well as unit symbols for EM units, to close Issue #1005. 

UPDATE: Responded to @ngoldbaum's suggestions.
